sen.j: かまど神（かまどがみ）はかまどや囲炉裏などの火を使う場所に祀られる神。
sen.e: Kamado-gami is a god enshrined at the furnace or irori fireplace (open hearth) where fire is used.

sen.j: 火の神であると同様に農業や家畜、家族を守る守護神ともされる。
sen.e: Kamado-gami is a Kami of fire and at the same time is a guardian god who protects agriculture, livestock, and family.

sen.e: In Tohoku area such as Miyagi prefecture, Iwate prefecture, a clay or wooden ugly mask called Kamaotoko (cauldron male), Hyottoko (Hiotoko), or Kamajin is hanged on the pillar near the kamado (kitchen range, cooking stove) and enshrined.

sen.j: 日本の仏教における尊像・三宝荒神は、かまど神として祀られることで知られる。
sen.e: Statue of a noble character, sanpokojin (guardian deity of Buddha the sutras and the sangha) in Buddhism in Japan is known to be enshrined as a Kamado-gami.

sen.e: Because this god respects cleanliness and remotes uncleanliness, that fact is considered to be linked to a Kami of fire.
Because this is a god who values cleanliness and eliminates impurities, he is considered to be linked to the Kami of fire.

sen.j: また近畿地方や中国地方では、陰陽道の神・土公神がかまど神として祀られた。
sen.e: In Kinki region or Chugoku region, the god of Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements) or Doku-shin, Doko-jin is enshrined as a Kamado-gami.

sen.j: 季節ごとに春はかまど、夏は門、秋は井戸、冬は庭へ移動すると考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that the god moves from one place to another depending on season: Furnace in Spring, gate in Summer, and well in Fall, and garden in Winter.

sen.j: したがって、影や裏側の領域、霊界（他界）と現世との境界を構成する場所とし、かまど神を両界の媒介、秩序の更新といった役割を持つ両義的な神とする考え方もある。
sen.e: Therefore, there is this idea that a kamado forms a boundary between dark side, underworld, or reikai (next world) and Utsushiyo (actual world), and that Kamado-gami is an ambiguous god who plays a role as a mediator between both worlds and as a regenerator of order.
